{{other people||Lev Leviev (disambiguation){{!}}Lev Leviev}} {{Infobox person | name = Lev Binzumovich Leviev | image = Lev Leviev (crop).jpg | alt = | caption = |birth_name=Lev Binzumovich Leviev | birth_date = {{birth-date and age|June 22, 1984}} | birth_place = [[Volgograd]], [[Soviet Union]] | residence = | citizenship = | education = | occupation = Entrepreneur, investor | known_for = co-founder of the [[VK.com]] and [[Selectel]] | networth = {{steady}} [[United States dollar|US $]] 218 million (est.)
''(2012)'' | boards = | spouse = | children = | website = }} '''Lev Binzumovich Leviev''' (born June 22, 1984, Volgograd) is a [[Israel]]i-[[Russia]]n entrepreneur and investor, co-founder of Russia's largest social network ''[[VK (social networking website)|VK.com]]'' (originally ''VKontakte'') and the ''[[Selectel]]'' data center network.{{cite web |url=http://www.cnews.ru/news/line/lev_leviev_vozglavil_selektel |title=Lev Leviev runs Selectel as CEO |author= |date=2014-09-24 |language=Russian |publisher=CNews.ru |accessdate=2018-11-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140925102006/http://www.cnews.ru/news/line/index.shtml?2014%2F09%2F24%2F586964 |archivedate=2014-09-25 |df= }} == Biography == Lev Leviev grew up in the family of a [[Volgograd]] entrepreneur and went to an American school in [[Herzliya, Israel]], where he met his future business partner [[Vyacheslav Mirilashvili]]. In 2006, he graduated with a bachelor of Commerce degree in Finance and Accounting at [[McGill University]] in [[Canada]].{{cite web | url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2013-08-01/is-pavel-durov-russias-zuckerberg-a-kremlin-target | title=Is Pavel Durov, Russia's Zuckerberg, a Kremlin Target? | author=Joshua Yaffa | date=2013-08-01 | language= | publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] | accessdate=2018-11-09 }} Married. {{cite web | url=http://www.the-village.ru/village/business/hf/147577-reyting-samyh-uspeshnyh-predprinimateley-rossii#ЛЕВИЕВ | title=Rating the Best Russian Young Entrepreneurs | author= | date= 2012-11-22 | publisher=Hopes&Fears |language=Russian | accessdate=2018-11-09 }} == Net worth == In 2012, a Hopes&Fears magazine established his net worth to be $218 mln. In 2014, he ranked 66th in the rating of the financial magazine “Delovoy Peterburg” with ₽11,4 bln,{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=The richest people of St. Petersburg |url=https://www.dp.ru/a/2014/09/17/Samie_bogatie_ljudi_Peterb/ |work=dp.ru |publisher=JSC "DP Business Press" |date=2014-09-17 |accessdate=2018-11-15 |lang=ru }} in 2015 - 42nd with ₽20 bln{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=The ranking of billionaires. The richest people of St. Petersburg |url=https://www.dp.ru/a/2015/09/18/200_milliarderov_Peterbur/ |work=dp.ru |publisher=JSC "DP Business Press" |date=2015-09-21 |accessdate=2018-11-15 |lang=ru }} and in 2016 — 43rd with ₽25,2 bln.{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title="DP" has prepared a new rating of billionaires " the richest people of St. Petersburg" |url=https://www.dp.ru/a/2016/09/27/Rejting_milliarderov_2016 |work=dp.ru |publisher=JSC "DP Business Press" |date=2016-09-29 |accessdate=2018-11-15 |lang=ru }} == Entrepreneurship == === VK.com === {{Main|VK (social networking)}} After graduating in 2006, he moved to Saint Petersburg and founded ''VK.com'' with his friends Vyacheslav Mirilashvili and Pavel Durov.{{cite web |url=http://www.arcticstartup.com/2011/07/18/the-story-and-plans-of-vkontakte-told-by-founder-and-ceo |title=The Story And Plans Of Vkontakte Told By Founder And CEO |author=Anna Bessonova |date=2011-07-18 |language=eng |publisher=Arctic Startup |accessdate=2018-11-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402135657/http://www.arcticstartup.com/2011/07/18/the-story-and-plans-of-vkontakte-told-by-founder-and-ceo |archivedate=2015-04-02 |df= }} Lev and Vyacheslav invested tens of thousands of dollars in the project. The money was borrowed from Mirilashvili-Sr. Leviev’s share was 10%. From the moment of founding the company till 2012 he was the Chief Operating Officer of VK. [[Yuri Milner]]'s ''Digital Sky Technologies'' fund was the company’s first external investor. He bought a quarter of the network in 2007 and later merged DST’s shareholdings into the ''[[Mail.Ru Group]]'' later. In the end of 2010, the holding increased its VK shares by 7,5% - from 24,99% to 32,49%. In addition, the new shareholder secured the [[Option (finance)|option]] of buying another 7,5% of VK.com in 2011. In July, 2011 Mail.ru exercised the option and increased their shareholding to 39,99% which decreased the total share of the partners from 55,5% to 48,01% making Lev’s share either 6% or 8%, according to different sources.{{cite web | url=http://rbth.com/science_and_tech/2014/07/12/russias_zuckerberg_loses_his_facebook_38107.html | title=Russia’s Zuckerberg loses his Facebook | author=Yevgeny Trifonov | date=2014-07-12 | language=en | publisher=Russia Beyond The Headlines | accessdate=2018-11-15 }} Having learned about negotiations between co-founders and [[Alisher Usmanov]] in March 2012, Durov deleted their profiles id3 and id4. Leviev and Mirilashvili were planning to exit VK investment via the [[IPO]] for $3 bln, but in the end of March, Durov announced that social network will not IPO for an undefined period.{{cite web | url=https://globalvoicesonline.org/2013/04/30/pavel-durov-russias-zuckerberg-fights-for-control-of-his-creation/ | title=Pavel Durov, Russia's Zuckerberg, Fights for Control of His Creation | author=Kevin Rothrock | date=2013-04-30 | language=en | publisher=Global Voices | accessdate=2018-11-15 }} In April 2013, It is estimated that [[Ilya Sherbovich]] investment fund ''[[United Capital Partners]]'' payed $840 mln for a partner’s share{{cite web | url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2013-04-18/usmanov-plan-to-control-vkontakte-said-to-be-rebuffed-by-ucp-2- | title=Usmanov Plan to Control VKontakte Said to Be Rebuffed by UCP | author=Irina Reznik. Ilya Khrennikov | date=2013-04-18 | language=en | publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] | accessdate=2015-04-21 }}, assuming the whole network’s worth at $1,75 bln. Leviev could get $105-140 mln. During the conflict between ''UCP'' and Pavel Durov, the fund considered Lev Leviev as a potential CEO of VK.{{cite web | url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/a-russian-social-network-tale-censorship-and-a-ceo-on-the-run/article19577825/?page=all | title=A Russian social network tale: Censorship and a CEO on the run | date=2014-07-12 | author=James Bradshaw | language=en | publisher=The Globe and Mail | accessdate=2015-04-21 }} === Selectel === {{Main|Selectel}} In 2007 Lev Leviev and Vyacheslav Mirilashvili founded ''Selectel'' data center to provide for ''VK''’s needs in processing and storing servers.{{cite web |url=http://rusbase.com/news/author/benhopkins/vkontaktes-annual-revenue-rises-profits-fall/ |title=VKontakte's annual revenue rises, but profits fall |author= |date=2013-04-29 |language= |publisher=Rusbase.com |accessdate=2015-04-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150420005747/http://rusbase.com/news/author/benhopkins/vkontaktes-annual-revenue-rises-profits-fall/ |archivedate=2015-04-20 |df= }} By 2009, ''VK.com''’s full server capacity was managed by ''Selectel''. In 2012, ''VK'' opened its own data center, but it still remains to be a client of ''Selectel''. After selling his ''VK'' shares in September 2014, Lev Leviev became CEO at ''Selectel''. In May 2014 it was reported that ''Selectel'' was investing ₽1 bln in a technopark in [[Saint Petersburg]] that would include a data center, offices and warehouses.{{cite web | url=http://www.ewdn.com/2014/06/13/vkontakte-cofounders-building-technopark-in-st-petersburg/ | title=Vkontakte cofounders building technopark in St. Petersburg | author= | date=2014-06-13 | language= | publisher=East-West Digital News | accessdate=2018-11-15 }} On December 17 2015, in the presence of Saint Petersburg governor Georgi Poltavchenko, Leviev opened the largest data-centre in the North-West of Russia, “Tsvetochnaya 2”.{{cite web | url=http://gov.spb.ru/press/governor/78954/ | title=The largest data center in the North-West began its work in St. Petersburg | date=2015-12-17 | publisher=The Administration Of St. Petersburg | accessdate=2018-11-15 |lang=ru }} In the end of 2016 ''Selectel'' ranked fourth largest IaaS provider for public and hybrid cloud in Russia based on revenue.{{cite news |first=Nicholay |last=Nosov |coauthors= |title=OpenStack: life after the hype |url=http://www.iksmedia.ru/articles/5491304-OpenStack-zhizn-posle-xajpa.html |work=iksmedia.ru |publisher=JSC «IKS-media» |date=2018-04-17 |accessdate=2018-11-15 |lang=ru }} In 2017, the company was one of the largest IaaS providers in Russia, with a market share of 7%.{{cite news |first=Alena |last=Zhuravleva |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Clouds grow due to SaaS |url=http://www.mskit.ru/news/n208625/ |work=MSKIT |publisher=Publishing house «Regional PR group» |date=2018-06-20 |accessdate=2018-11-15 |lang=ru }} In the end of 2017, Lev stepped down from the CEO position, while remaining the chairman of the board of directors. === Btc.com === In 2014, Lev co-founded ''BlockTrail'' with his long time friend, Boaz Bechar. Lev set up the holding company ''BlockCorp'' which made an initial investment of 500k euros in the ''BlockTrail'' project. The company developed block explorer, [[bitcoin]] transaction analytic tools and multi-platform bitcoin wallets.{{cite web | url=http://www.coindesk.com/russian-tech-magnates-first-bitcoin-project-launches-beta/ | title=Russian Tech Magnate's First Bitcoin Project Launches in Beta | author=Joon Ian Wong | date=2014-08-18 | language=en | publisher=CoinDesk.com | accessdate=2018-11-15 }}{{cite news |first=Mike |last=Butcher |coauthors= |title=BlockTrail Secures Cash For Its Bitcoin Transactions Analysis Platform |url=https://techcrunch.com/2014/08/18/blocktrail-secures-cash-for-its-bitcoin-transactions-analysis-platform/ |work=Oath Tech Network |publisher=Oath Inc. |date=2014-07-29 |accessdate=2018-11-15 |lang=en}} In 2016 the project was bought by a Chinese producer of equipment for mining bitcoins ''[[Bitmain]]'' and renamed to ''BTC Wallet'' (btc.com).{{cite web | url=https://www.coindesk.com/bitcoin-miner-bitmain-acquires-blockchain-data-startup/ | title=Bitcoin Miner Bitmain Acquires Data Startup Blocktrail| author=Pete Rizzo | date=2016-07-19 | language=en | publisher=CoinDesk.com | accessdate=2018-11-15 }} == Investments == === Russian investments === Since 2011, Lev Leviev has actively invested in the Russian technological sector both as a private investor and as a partner of the ''Vaizra Capital'' fund.{{cite web | url=https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/vaizra-investments | title=Vaizra Investments | author= | date= | language= | publisher=[[Techcrunch]] | accessdate=2015-11-15 }} Such investments include: * 2012 — ''Komitet'', media holding company that operates three online media platforms - ''Tjournal.ru'', ''Vc.ru'', ''DTF.ru''. * 2014 — ''[[Coub]]'' (a Russian platform for making looped videos){{cite web | url=https://calvertjournal.com/news/show/2942/russian-video-app-coub-raises-2.5-million-investment | title=Russian video app Coub raises $2.5m investment | author=Nadia Beard | date=2014-07-29 | language= | publisher=The Calvert Journal | accessdate=2018-11-15 }}{{cite news |first=Steve |last=O'Hear |coauthors= |title=Video Re-Mix Startup Coub Raises $2.5 Million From VC Fund Headed Up By VK.com Founders |url=https://techcrunch.com/2014/07/29/coub-funding-loop/ |work=Oath Tech Network |publisher=Oath Inc. |date=2014-07-29 |accessdate=2018-11-15 |lang=en}}, ''[[Livetex]]'' (a service for online communication){{cite web | url=http://www.owler.com/iaApp/article/53c398dfe4b0e2a68af60ab2.htm | title=Online communication tool developer Livetex obtains $4 million from Vaizra Capital | author= | date=2014-07-09 | language= | publisher=East-West Digital News | accessdate=2018-11-15 }}, ''[[Ostrovok.ru]]'' (a Russian Online Travel Agency).{{cite web | url=https://techcrunch.com/2014/06/18/ostrovok-raises-new-12m-series-c-round-to-expand-outside-russia/ | title=Ostrovok Raises New $12M Series C Round To Expand Outside Russia | author=Mike Butcher | date=2018-11-15 | language=en | publisher=[[Techcrunch]] | accessdate=2018-11-15 }} === International investments === Lev Leviev has also invested in international projects, such as: * 2013 - ''[[Plarium]]'' (a game developer; in 2017 the company was sold to an [[Australia]]n producer of slot machines ''[[Aristocrat Leisure]]'' for $500 mln);{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Mirilashvili and Leviev have sold 48% of Vkontakte, the Fund United Capital Partners |url=https://roem.ru/17-04-2013/116668/mirilashvili-i-leviev-prodali-48-vkontakte-fondu-united-capital-partners/ |work=Roem.ru |publisher=JSC «Roem» |date=2013-04-17 |accessdate=2018-11-15 }}{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Aristocrat Leisure to acquire 100% of Plarium Global Ltd |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/brief-aristocrat-leisure-to-acquire-idUSFWN1KV15A |work=Reuters |publisher=Thomson Reuters |date=2017-08-10 |accessdate=2018-11-15 |lang=en}} * 2015 – ''[[Optishell]]'' (a developer of a technology for identifying illegal filming in cinemas),{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Co-founders of VK Leviev and Mirilashvili invested in the development of protection against film piracy |url=https://roem.ru/06-05-2015/194680/ex-vk-antiekranka/ |work=Roem.ru |publisher=JSC «Roem» |date=2015-05-06 |accessdate=2018-11-15 }} ''[[Moovit]]'' (a mobile app for planning routes travelling by [[public transport]].{{cite news |first=Mike |last=Butcher |coauthors= |title=Moovit Raises $50M To Scale Its Public Transit App, Goes Up Against CityMapper |url=https://techcrunch.com/2015/01/14/moovit-raises-50m-to-scale-its-public-trans-app-goes-up-against-citymapper/ |work=Oath Tech Network |publisher=Oath Inc. |date=2015-01-14 |accessdate=2018-11-15 |lang=en}}{{cite web |url=https://moovitapp.com/blog/funding-series-d-intel/ |title=Moovit Raises $50 Million Led by Intel Capital to Expand its Global Urban Mobility Operating System |publisher=Moovit |accessdate=2018-11-15 |lang=en }} === DST Global === Lev Leviev is an investors of ''[[DST Global]] II'' fund and ''DST Global IV'' fund of [[Yuri Milner]]. ''DST Global II owns shares of ''[[Facebook]]'', ''[[Twitter]]'', ''[[Airbnb]]'', ''[[Spotify]]'', ''[[Alibaba]]'' and ''[[Xiaomi]]''.{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=The former shareholders of VK.com became the shareholders of the two funds of Yuri Milner |url=https://roem.ru/28-04-2015/193958/leviev-mirilashvili-dst/ |work=Roem.ru |publisher=JSC «Roem» |date=2015-04-28 |accessdate=2018-11-15 |lang=ru }} Among the famous investments of ''DST Global IV'' are an Indian car service ''[[Ola Cabs]]'',{{cite news |first=Samidha |last=Sharma |coauthors= |title=DST may invest up to $500m in Ola at $2.5bn valuation |url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/india-business/DST-may-invest-up-to-500m-in-Ola-at-2-5bn-valuation/articleshow/46375927.cms |work=The Times of India |publisher=Bennett, Coleman & Co. Ltd. |date=2015-02-26 |accessdate=2018-11-15 |lang=en}} an Indian online shop ''[[Flipkart]]''{{cite news |first=Samidha |last=Sharma |coauthors= |title=Udaan raises $225 million at $1 billion from Yuri Milner’s DST, Lightspeed |url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/india-business/udaan-raises-225-million-at-1-billion-from-yuri-milners-dst-lightspeed/articleshow/65650346.cms |work=The Times of India |publisher=Bennett, Coleman & Co. Ltd. |date=2018-09-03 |accessdate=2018-11-15 |lang=en}} and a developer of the corporate messenger [[Slack (software)|Slack]].{{cite news |first=Ingrid |last=Lunden |coauthors= |title=Used Daily By 750K Workers, Slack Raises $160M, Valuing Collaboration Startup At $2.8B |url=https://techcrunch.com/2015/04/16/used-daily-by-750k-workers-slack-raises-160m-to-value-collaboration-startup-at-2-8b/ |work=Oath Tech Network |publisher=Oath Inc. |date=2015-04-16 |accessdate=2018-11-15 |lang=en}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Leviev, Lev Binzumovich}} [[Category:1984 births]] [[Category:Technology company founders]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Russian chief executives]] [[Category:Russian investors]] [[Category:Russian Jews]] [[Category:Israeli Jews]] [[Category:Israeli mass media owners]] [[Category:People from Volgograd]] [[Category:McGill University alumni]]

page.title: List of Swiss inventions and discoveries

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=April 2013}}
The following list is composed of items, techniques and processes that were invented by or discovered by people from [[Switzerland]].
== Biology == [[File:DNA Structure+Key+Labelled.pn NoBB.png|thumb|right|100px|DNA structure]] * [[Nucleic acid]], [[DNA]] by [[Friedrich Miescher]] (1868)<ref>{{cite journal |pmid=17901982 |date=Jan 2008 |author=Dahm, R |title=Discovering DNA: Friedrich Miesc research |volume=122 |issue=6 |pages=565–81 |issn=0340-6717 |doi=10.1007/s00439-007-0433-0 |journal=Human Genetics}}</ref> * [[Restriction endonuclease]] by [[Werner Arber]] * Research of the [[Immune system]] by [[Rolf M. Zinkernagel]]
== Chemistry == * [[Laudanum]] by [[Paracelsus]] * [[Aluminium foil]] by [[Robert Victor Neher]]<ref>{{cite web|author=Mary Bellis |url=http://inventors.about.com/library/inventors/blaluminum.htm |title=Charles Martin Hall - The History of Aluminum |publisher=Inventors.about.com |date=2012-04-09 |accessdate=2012-12-28}}</ref> [[Image:Cellofan.jpg|thumb|100px|Cellophane bag]] * [[Cellophane]] by [[Jacques E. Brandenberger]] * [[DDT]] by [[Paul Hermann Müller]] * [[Lysergic acid diethylamide]] (LSD) by [[Albert Hofmann]] * [[Reichstein process]] by [[Tadeus Reichstein]] * [[Glyphosate]] by [[Henri Martin (chemist)|Henri Martin]] <!-- http://www.glyphosat.de/geschichte-von-glyphosat -->
== Clothes and Fashion ==
* [[Velcro]] by [[George de Mestral]]
== Computing ==
* [[Computer mouse]] by [[René Sommer]], co-inventor<ref>{{cite news|first= |last= |title=Computer mouse inventor dies in Vaud |url=http://worldradio.ch/wrs/news/wrsnews/computer-mouse-inventor-dies-in-vaud.shtml?16283 |work=[[World Radio Switzerland]] |publisher= |date=2009-10-14 |accessdate=2009-10-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707010602/http://worldradio.ch/wrs/news/wrsnews/computer-mouse-inventor-dies-in-vaud.shtml?16283 |archivedate=2011-07-07 |df= }}</ref> * [[Smaky]] by [[Jean-Daniel Nicoud]] * programming language [[Pascal (programming language)|Pascal]] by [[Niklaus Wirth]]
== Cuisine ==
* [[Absinthe]] [[File:Muesli.jpg|thumb|right|100px|Dry muesli mix, served with milk]] * [[Muesli]] by [[Maximilian Bircher-Benner]] * [[White chocolate]] by Nestle * [[Immersion blender]] by [[Roger Perrinjaquet]]
== Economics == * Discovery of [[economic cycles]] and propagation of [[Social policy]] against the classic liberal economy by [[Simonde de Sismondi]] * [[Bank secrecy]]
== Medicine ==
* [[Laudanum]] by [[Paracelsus]] * [[Diclofenac]] (''Voltaren'') (1973, company Ciba-Geigy) * [[Panthenol]] (''Bepanthen'') (1944, company Roche)
== Military == [[File:My swiss army knife.JPG|thumb|right|100px|Victorinox "Huntsman" Swiss Army knife]] * [[Swiss Army knife]] * [[Full Metal Jacket bullet]]
== Physics ==
* [[Argand lamp]] by [[Aimé Argand]] * [[Twisted nematic field effect]] by [[Brown, Boveri & Cie]] * [[Scanning tunneling microscope]] by [[Heinrich Rohrer]] (co-inventor with German [[Gerd Binnig]]) * [[Super-twisted nematic display]] by [[Brown, Boveri & Cie]] * [[Swatch Internet Time]] by [[Swatch]] * Research on [[Nuclear Magnetic Resonance]] by [[Kurt Wüthrich]]
== Sports == [[Image:Bobfahrer Davos.jpg|thumb|right|100px|The Swiss bobsleigh team from [[Davos]], ca. 1910]] * [[Bobsleigh]]
==Technology== * [[Constant escapement]] by [[Girard-Perregaux]] * [[Cross-beat escapement]] and [[remontoire]] for watches by [[Jost Bürgi]] * [[Riggenbach rack system]] by [[Niklaus Riggenbach]] * [[Solar Impulse]] by [[Bertrand Piccard]] in co-operation with [[EPFL]] * [[Tourbillon]] by [[Abraham-Louis Breguet]] * [[Turbocharger]] by [[Alfred Büchi]]
== Transportation ==
* [[Bathyscaphe Trieste]] by [[Auguste Piccard]]
== Miscellaneous ==
* [[International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement|The Red Cross]] by [[Henry Dunant]]
==See also== [[List of Swiss inventors and discoverers]]
== References == <references/>
{{Inventions}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Swiss Inventions And Discoveries}} [[Category:Swiss inventions| ]] [[Category:Switzerland history-related lists]] [[Category:Lists of inventions or discoveries|Switzerland]]

revision.comment: /* List */ link to the main pages of different countries
revision.text:
{{Pp-move-indef}} {{Main article|Film censorship}} This is a '''list of banned films'''.
For nearly the entire [[history of film]] production, certain films have been [[Ban (law)|banned]] by film censorship or review organizations for political or [[morality|moral]] reasons or for controversial content, such as racism. Censorship standards vary widely by country, and can vary within an individual country over time due to political or moral change.
Many countries have government-appointed or private commissions to censor and rate productions for film and television exhibition. While it is common for films to be edited to fall into certain rating classifications, this list includes only films that have been explicitly prohibited from public screening.
{{horizontal TOC|nonum=yes}}
==List==
:''Note that for some countries films are banned on a wide scale and are not listed in this table.'' :''Separate lists for some countries are listed below this table'' <!--
PLEASE UPDATE THE ARTICLE FOR INDIVIDUAL COUNTRIES WHERE THEY EXIST
--> {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width:100%;" |- ! style="width:8%;"|Date ! style="width:22%;"|Title ! style="width:10%;"|Country/Organization !! class="unsortable" style="width:60%;"|Notes |- |align=center | 1996–2001 | '''All''' |align=center | [[Afghanistan]] | During the [[Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan|five-year reign]] of the [[Taliban]] government in Afghanistan, Western technology and art was prohibited and this included ''all'' films.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lang.sbsun.com/socal/terrorist/1101/20/terror09.asp|title=After five-year Taliban ban, television and movies return to Afghanistan|publisher=Lang.sbsun.com|accessdate=2015-02-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rawa.org/rules.htm|title=some of the restrictions imposed by Taliban in Afghanistan|publisher=Rawa.org|accessdate=2015-02-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NubtDf2T3cAC&pg=PA84|title=Inside Afghanistan|accessdate=2015-02-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bunHURgi7FcC&pg=PA7|title=Encyclopedia of Censorship|accessdate=2015-02-16}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1980–1990 | ''Pas vdekjes'' (''After Death'') |align=center | [[Albania]] | Banned for ten years.<ref name="kviff">{{cite web|url=http://www.kviff.com/en/programme/film/082582-magic-eye/|title=KVIFF | Magic Eye|publisher=kviff.com|accessdate=2016-07-12}}</ref> |- |align=center| 2017 | ''[[Wonder Woman (2017 film)|Wonder Woman]]'' |align=center | [[Lebanon]], [[Qatar]], and [[Tunisia]] | Pulled from distribution in [[Lebanon]] before premiere on account of that film's lead star [[Gal Gadot]]'s service in the [[Israeli Army]], leading to a campaign against her and in accordance with a decades-old law that boycotts Israeli products and bars Lebanese citizens from traveling to Israel or having contacts with Israelis. Lebanon is at war with Israel. However, that film will be viewed online and available on DVD instead.<ref name="Page Six">{{cite news|title=Lebanon officially bans 'Wonder Woman'|url=http://pagesix.com/2017/06/01/lebanon-officially-bans-wonder-woman/|accessdate=3 June 2017|work=Page Six|agency=Associated Press|date=1 June 2017}}</ref> Due to the [[Arab League boycott of Israel]], it is also banned in [[Qatar]] and [[Tunisia]].<ref>http://www.jpost.com/Not-Just-News/Tunisian-court-bans-showing-of-Wonder-Woman-over-Gal-Gadots-IDF-service-496590</ref><ref>http://www.jpost.com/Arab-Israeli-Conflict/Qatar-bans-Wonder-Woman-over-lead-Israeli-actress-Gal-Gadot-498595</ref> |- |align=center | 1941 | ''[[I'll Never Heil Again]]'' | rowspan="13" align="center" | [[Argentina]] | Banned during the "[[Infamous Decade]]" dictatorship (1930-1943) for lampooning [[Nazi Germany]]; Argentina had declared itself [[Neutral powers during World War II|neutral during World War Two]].<ref name="latimes1">{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/opinion/opinion-la/la-ol-north-korea-the-interview-banned-movies-20141222-story.html |title=Beyond 'The Interview': A short list of films banned for political reasons |publisher=LA Times |date=2014-12-23 |accessdate=2016-01-11}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1963 | ''[[The Silence (1963 film)|The Silence]]'' | Banned because of "obscenity".<ref name="google1969">{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gDqsCQAAQBAJ&pg=PA807 |title=Censorship: A World Encyclopedia |page=807 |date=2015-05-22 |accessdate=2016-01-11}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1972 | ''[[Last Tango in Paris]]'' | Banned during the self-styled "[[Argentine Revolution]]" dictatorship (1966-1973), for being "pornographic".<ref name="google1969"/> |- |align=center | 1974 | ''[[La Patagonia rebelde]]'' (''Rebel Patagonia'') | Banned under [[Isabel Perón]]'s government (1974-1975) and [[Jorge Rafael Videla]]'s regime during [[National Reorganization Process|Argentina's last-civil military dictatorship]] (1976-1983). The historical film is about the suppression of a peasants' revolt, known as "[[Patagonia Trágica|Tragic Patagonia]]".<ref name="google1969" /> |- |align=center | 1976 | ''[[The Great Dictator]]'' (1940) | Banned under Videla's regime during Argentina's last-civil military dictatorship (1976-1983), for mocking dictatorships.<ref name="google1969"/> |- |align=center | 1978 | ''[[Long Vacations of 36|Las largas vacaciones del '36]]'' | Banned under Videla's regime during Argentina's last-civil military dictatorship (1976-1983), for its sarcastic view of [[Francoist Spain]].<ref name="google1969"/> |- |align=center | 1978 | ''[[Looking for Mr. Goodbar]]'' | Banned under Videla's regime during Argentina's last-civil military dictatorship (1976-1983), for being "pornographic".<ref name="google1969" /> |- |align=center | 1978 | ''[[Pretty Baby (1978 film)|Pretty Baby]]'' | Banned under Videla's regime during Argentina's last-civil military dictatorship (1976-1983), for being "pornographic".<ref name="google1969" /> |- |align=center | 1979 | ''[[Coming Home (1978 film)|Coming Home]]'' | Banned under Videla's regime during Argentina's last-civil military dictatorship (1976-1983), for its anti-war message.<ref name="google1969"/> |- |align=center | 1979 | ''[[The House on Garibaldi Street]]'' | Banned under Videla's regime during Argentina's last-civil military dictatorship (1976-1983), because it depicts the hunt for Nazi criminal [[Adolf Eichmann]].<ref name="google1969"/> |- |align=center | 1985 | ''[[Hail Mary (film)|Je vous salue, Marie]]'' (''Hail Mary'') | Banned due to blasphemous and sexual content.<ref>{{cite book | title = The Films Of Jean-Luc Godard (Cambridge Film Classics) | author = Sterritt, David | publisher = Cambridge University Press | isbn = 0-521-58971-1 | year = 2003 | page = 166}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1987 | ''[[The Last Temptation of Christ (film)|The Last Temptation of Christ]]'' | Banned for being considered as "blasphemy".<ref name="criterion1">{{cite web|url=https://www.criterion.com/lists/170366-banned-criterion-s-forbidden-films |title=Banned! Criterion's Forbidden Films |website=Criterion.com |date= |accessdate=2016-01-11}}</ref>{{Better source|reason=Citation is a list developed by a user from the Criterion site.|date=June 2017}}<ref>[http://malditosnerds.com/notas/id/12225/10-pelculas-prohibidas-en-Argentina#9 Ten films banned in Argentina] Malditos Nerds {{es}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1989 | ''[[Kindergarten (1989 film)|Kindergarten]]'' | Banned for its controversial themes, scenes of nudity and [[Unsimulated sex|unsimulated]] [[Fellatio|oral sex]]. A [[court order]] required all copies of the film to be seized and a ban on its exhibition.<ref>[https://books.google.com.ar/books?id=gDqsCQAAQBAJ&pg=PA1881&lpg=PA1881&dq=kindergarten+1989+censored+film&source=bl&ots=_6C_4uJm1M&sig=QnVc7j3ZWWempqzrfvgJQ3_FxSg&hl=es&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiY7_2Qqs3ZAhXmw1kKHWRCAVkQ6AEIcDAM#v=onepage&q=kindergarten%201989%20censored%20film&f=false Censorship: A World Encyclopedia (edited by Derek Jones)] [[Google Books]]</ref> The film was finally shown in a restored copy in 2010, as part of the [[Mar del Plata International Film Festival]].<ref>[http://www.clarin.com/espectaculos/cine/Kindergarten_0_374362762.html Forbidden film "Kindergarten" is released after 21 years] 11-18-2010, ''[[Clarín (Argentine newspaper)|Clarín]]'' {{es}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1972 | ''[[Pink Flamingos]]'' | rowspan="5" align="center" |{{main|List of films banned in Australia}} | Banned on its initial release until the 1980s due to offensive content.<ref name="anothermag1">{{cite web|url=http://www.anothermag.com/design-living/7505/the-best-banned-films |title=The Best Banned Films | AnOther |website=Anothermag.com |date=2015-06-12 |accessdate=2016-01-11}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1975–1992 | ''[[Salò, or the 120 Days of Sodom]]'' | Banned on its initial release,<ref name="google1969"/> but lifted after seventeen years.<ref name="berlinfilmjournal1">{{cite web|last=Beaney |first=Harriet |url=http://berlinfilmjournal.com/2014/09/controversial-cinema-top-10-banned-films/ |title=Controversial Cinema: Top 10 Banned Films |publisher=Berlin Film Journal |date= |accessdate=2016-01-11}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1976–2000 | ''[[In the Realm of the Senses]]'' | Banned because of obscenity, though a censored version was made available in 1977. The Criterion Collection |publisher=Criterion.com |date= |accessdate=2016-01-22}}</ref>{{Better source|reason=Citation is a list developed by a user from the Criterion site.|date=June 2017}} |- |align=center | 1968 | ''Deserters and Pilgrims'' (also known as ''The Deserters and the Nomads'') | Banned by the Czech Communist government.<ref name="google9"/> |- |align=center | 1969–1990 | ''[[All My Compatriots]]'' (also known as ''All My Countrymen'') | Banned by the Czech Communist government.<ref name="google9"/> Its director, [[Vojtěch Jasný]] went into exile. |- |align=center | 1969–1990 | ''[[Birds, Orphans and Fools]]'' | Banned by the Czech Communist government for depicting three people orphaned by political violence and trying to mentally survive, despite not being free.<ref name="google9"/> |- |align=center | 1969–1989 | ''Dull Sunday'' | Banned by the Czech Communist government for twenty years, with its director, Drahomíra Vihanová, being banned from making new films until 1977.<ref name="google9" /> |- |align=center | 1969–1989 | ''[[The Cremator]]'' | Banned by the Czech Communist government from 1969 until 1989 because this black comedy depicts a [[crematorium]] director who enjoys burning people and sides with the Nazis during the Holocaust. Apart from this theme, the story can be interpreted for remaining true to individual morality, something that was a dangerous message.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.johncoulthart.com/feuilleton/2013/08/20/the-cremator-by-juraj-herz/ |title=The Cremator by Juraj Herz |publisher=Johncoulthart.com |date=2013-08-20 |accessdate=2016-01-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://sensesofcinema.com/2007/feature-articles/cremator-juraj-herz/ |title=A Black Pearl of the Deep: Juraj Herz's The Cremator • Senses of Cinema |publisher=Sensesofcinema.com |date= |accessdate=2016-01-22}}</ref><ref name="kinoeye1">{{cite web|author=Ivana Košuličová |url=http://www.kinoeye.org/02/01/kosulicova01.php |title=Czech Horror: Juraj Herz interviewed |publisher=Kinoeye |date= |accessdate=2016-01-22}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1969–1990 | ''[[Larks on a String]]'' | Banned under the Communist regime from 1969 until the fall of the regime in 1990.<ref>{{cite news|last=Maslin |first=Janet |url=https://www.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9D0CEEDA173DF930A25751C0A967958260 |title=Movie Review - Larks on a String - Review/Film; Long-Repressed Tale of Repression |website=NYTimes.com |date=1991-02-13 |accessdate=2016-01-11}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6He0BgAAQBAJ&pg=PA363 |title=The Rough Guide to Film |author1=Jessica Winter |author2=Lloyd Hughes |author3=Richard Armstrong |author4=Tom Charity |page=363 |date= |accessdate=2016-01-11}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1969 | ''Mourning Party'' (''Smuteční slavnost'') | Banned by the Czech Communist government.<ref name="google9"/> |- |align=center | 1969 | ''The Seventh Day, The Eighth Night'' (''Den sedmý, osmá noc'') | Banned by the Czech Communist government.<ref name="google9"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://eefb.org/archive/september-2013/the-seventh-day-the-eighth-night/|title=The Seventh Day, the Eighth Night - East European Film Bulletin|publisher=}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1970 | ''Hlídac'' (''Prison Guard'') | Banned by the Czech Communist government.<ref name="google9"/> |- |align=center | 1970–1989 | ''[[Ucho]]'' (''The Ear'') | Banned by the Czech Communist government until 1989, because the story depicts a couple who think they are under government surveillance.<ref name="google9"/> |- |align=center | 1970 | ''[[Fruit of Paradise]]'' | Banned by the Czech Communist government for its shocking content. Its director, [[Vera Chytilová]], was forbidden from making new films for eight years.<ref name="google9"/><ref name=obituary>{{cite news|last1=Bergan|first1=Ronald|title=Vera Chytilová obituary|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/mar/14/vera-chytilova|accessdate=2015-11-29|agency=Guardian Media Group|publisher=Guardian News and Media|date=March 14, 2014}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1970 | ''[[Witchhammer]]'' | Banned by the Czech Communist government.<ref name="google9"/> |- |align=center | 1971 | ''Nahota'' (''Naked'') | Banned by the Czech Communist government.<ref name="google9"/> |- |align=center | 1972 | ''[[Case for a Rookie Hangman]]'' | Banned by the Czech Communist government for its satirical depiction of Czech society, which meant the end of the director [[Pavel Juráček]]'s career.<ref name="google9"/><ref name="ACMI">{{cite web|url=http://www.acmi.net.au/cinema_east_of_eden3.aspx |title=a case for the young hangman + late august at the hotel ozone |publisher=[[Australian Centre for the Moving Image]] |accessdate=2013-09-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130925203145/http://www.acmi.net.au/cinema_east_of_eden3.aspx |archivedate=2013-09-25 |df= }}</ref> |- |align=center | 1972 | ''[[Leonardo's Diary]]'' | Banned by the Communist government for depicting life in Czechoslovakia in a critical light. Its director, [[Jan Svankmajer]], was banned from working for five years. When the ban was lifted, he was only allowed to make adaptations of literary works.<ref name="google10">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SWCx_jpxkdwC&pg=PA212 |title=The Pleasure and Pain of Cult Horror Films: An Historical Survey - Bart?omiej Paszylk - Google Boeken |date= |accessdate=2016-01-22}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1975 | ''The Apple Game'' | Banned by the Czech Communist government. The director, [[Věra Chytilová]], personally asked for more information at the censor board and heard that the Soviet embassy felt the subject matter was "too heavy-duty".<ref name="google9"/> |- |align=center | 1977–1990 | ''[[Castle of Otranto (film)|Castle of Otranto]]'' | Banned by the Czech Communist government after its director, [[Jan Svankmajer]], refused to change anything about the film. Government censors objected to its [[mockumentary]] tone, which could undermine peoples' faith in the TV news. Svankmajer himself was banned from making films for eight years.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2011/dec/05/jan-svankmajer-puppets-politics |title=Jan Svankmajer: Puppets and politics | Film |publisher=The Guardian |date=2014-03-13 |accessdate=2016-01-11}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1982 | ''[[Dimensions of Dialogue]]'' | Banned because the Communist government censors didn't like its criticism of consumerism. While not directly referring to politics it still was perceived as dangerous criticism of the system.<ref name="AllanSandford1999">{{cite book|last1=Allan|first1=Seán|last2=Sandford|first2=John|title=DEFA: East German cinema, 1946-1992|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3xDwYDJlklkC&pg=PA146|accessdate=2011-04-06|year=1999|publisher=Berghahn Books|isbn=978-1-57181-753-2|page=146}}</ref> Due to the film's infamy all banned films in the DDR were referred to as "rabbit films". The film remained banned until Germany was unified again in 1990.<ref name="google11">{{cite book|title=The A to Z of German Cinema|author1=Reimer, R.C.|author2=Reimer, C.J.|date=2010|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810876118|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nqCa1YYd9ncC&pg=PA206|page=206|accessdate=2016-07-12}}</ref><ref name="google11">{{cite book|title=The A to Z of German Cinema|author1=Reimer, R.C.|author2=Reimer, C.J.|date=2010|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810876118|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nqCa1YYd9ncC&pg=PA206|page=206|accessdate=2016-07-12}}</ref><ref name="BockBergfelder2009">{{cite book|last1=Bock|first1=Hans-Michael|last2=Bergfelder|first2=Tim|title=The concise Cinegraph: encyclopaedia of German cinema|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=z7gFT_Duq1cC&pg=PA304|accessdate=2011-04-06|date=30 December 2009|publisher=Berghahn Books|isbn=978-1-57181-655-9|page=304}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1965–1990 | ''Denk bloss nicht, ich heule'' (''Just Don't Think I'll Cry'') | Banned by the East-German Communist government for its criticism of the regime.<ref name="google11">{{cite book|title=The A to Z of German Cinema|author1=Reimer, R.C.|author2=Reimer, C.J.|date=2010|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810876118|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nqCa1YYd9ncC&pg=PA206|page=206|accessdate=2016-07-12}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1966–1989 | ''Spur der Steine'' (''Trace of Stones'') | Banned by the East-German Communist government.<ref name="google11">{{cite book|title=The A to Z of German Cinema|author1=Reimer, R.C.|author2=Reimer, C.J.|date=2010|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810876118|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nqCa1YYd9ncC&pg=PA206|page=206|accessdate=2016-07-12}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1968–1989 | ''Die Russen kommen'' (''The Russians Are Coming'') | Banned by the East-German Communist government because of its theme where a young Nazi lives in fear of the approaching Russian army. ''The Films of Barbra Streisand'', Citadel Press (2000)</ref><ref name="theguardian">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/jul/10/omar-sharif|title=Omar Sharif obituary | Film | The Guardian|publisher=theguardian.com|accessdate=2016-07-12}}</ref> |- |align=center | 2006 | ''[[The Da Vinci Code (film)|The Da Vinci Code]]'' | Banned because of blasphemous content.<ref name="berlinfilmjournal1"/> |- |align=center | 2014 | ''Halawet Rooh'' (''Sweetness of Soul'') | Banned right after screening the film in cinemas, after criticism over scenes deemed sexually provocative. The movie was criticized for copying [[Giuseppe Tornatore]]'s movie ''[[Malèna|Malena]] (2000)'' starring Italian actress [[Monica Bellucci]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2014/film/global/egypt-film-censorship-spat-sparks-national-controversy-1201162859/|title=Egypt Film Censorship Spat Sparks National Controversy|author=Nick Vivarelli|work=Variety}}</ref><ref name="alarabiya">{{cite web|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/life-style/2014/04/17/Egypt-s-PM-orders-Haifa-Wehbe-s-film-to-be-pulled.html|title=Egypt pulls sexually explicit Haifa Wehbe film |publisher=english.alarabiya.net|accessdate=2016-07-12}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1930–1952 | ''[[Battleship Potemkin]]'' | rowspan="17" align="center" | [[Finland]] | Banned out of fear of inciting a Communist revolution.<ref name="latimes1"/><ref name="Sedergren 2006, s. 29–31">Sedergren 2006, s. 29–31.</ref> |- |align=center | 1943–1945 | ''[[Mrs. Miniver]]'' | Banned during World War II.<ref name="Internet Movie Database Miniver">{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0035093/releaseinfo|title=Mrs. Miniver (1942) – Release dates|accessdate=2013-04-14|work=Amazon.com, Inc.}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1943–1950 | ''[[Johnny Eager]]'' | Banned during World War II and finally released on March 31, 1950.<ref name="Internet Movie Database Eager">{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0033774/releaseinfo|title=Johnny Eager (1941) - Release dates|accessdate=2013-04-14|work=Amazon.com, Inc.}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1955–1959 | ''[[Rififi]]'' | Banned for its depiction of cracking security safes. Director of the Finnish Board of Film, Jerker Eeriksson, said that the banning of the film was political because it harmed the Finnish-Soviet relationship. Finnish television showed the film in 1996 on the TV1 YLE channel.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IeI3BAAAQBAJ&pg=PA113 |title=Filming the Unfilmable: Casper Wrede's One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich |author=Ben Hellmann |page=113 |date= |accessdate=2016-01-11}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lgPwzq0M9lkC&pg=PT78 |title=Solzhenitsyn: A Soul in Exile |author=Joseph Pearce |date= |accessdate=2016-01-11}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1974-1996<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.elonet.fi/fi/elokuva/773348 |title=Texas Chainsaw Massacre, The <nowiki>|</nowiki> Elonet | language=Finnish}}</ref> | ''[[The Texas Chain Saw Massacre]]'' | Banned because of graphic violence.<ref name="tonight ggs" /> |- |align=center | 1980 | ''[[Cruising (film)|Cruising]]'' | Banned on its initial release.<ref name="anothermag1"/> |- |align=center | 1980–2000 |''[[Friday the 13th (1980 film)|Friday the 13th]]'' |Banned on its initial release until a law change in 2001 when it automatically reverted to a K18 (adults only) classification.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2017-12-28|title=Perjantai 13. Finally a law change in 2001 removed the ban.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.elonet.fi/fi/elokuva/834708|title=Salò o le 120 giornate di Sodoma|work=Elonet|access-date=2018-03-15|language=fi}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1972 |''[[Dirty Harry]]'' |Banned on Feb-1972 for violence and mental health reasons. The distributor challenged the banning and took the decision to ban to Finnish Supreme administrative Court which ruled against banning. After minor cuts, it was banned again. A second round of court cases (again, won by the distributor) forced the banning authorities to allow the film to be distributed. They did so but only after mandatory cuts of over three minutes. Finally in Jan-1973 the butchered film premiered in Finland.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.elonet.fi/fi/elokuva/100787|title=Dirty Harry|work=Elonet|access-date=2018-03-15|language=fi}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1986 |''[[Born American]]'' |Banned on Jan-1986 for its violence and for political reasons.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.elonet.fi/fi/elokuva/113965|title=Born American|work=Elonet|access-date=2018-03-15|language=fi}}</ref> The political reasons were that the movie was "''potentially harmful to international relations''". A court appeal to Finnish Supreme administrative Court decided against the banning (after some cuts would be made) and authorities were forced to dismantle the ban (with more cuts) and the movie premiered in late Dec-1986 after a struggle of almost a year. 20 years after the movie was banned, it was revealed (by a politics researcher and academic [[Juhani Suomi]] in his book "''Kohti sinipunaa''") that the authorities were in fact "instructed" to ban the film and that the banning was dictated by the [[Soviet Union]]'s ambassador [[Vladimir Sobolev (diplomat)|Vladimir Sobolev]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/262737883|title=Kohti sinipunaa : Mauno Koiviston aika 1986-1987|last=1943-|first=Suomi, Juhani,|date=2008|publisher=Otava|isbn=9789511219699|location=Helsingissä|oclc=262737883}}</ref> Born American was the last movie in Finland to suffer banning for political reasons. |- |align=center | 1971–2000 |[[The Devils (film)|''The Devils'']] |Banned on its initial release in 1971 for violence and content which could potentially be hazardous to mental health. The decision to ban was ultimately taken to highest available court which did not lift the ban. A second round of banning was then seen in 1985 and the government officials used the same exact phrasing in their decision to ban as was done 14 years earlier. During [[World War II#Axis advance stalls (1942)|World War II]], it was once shown to German soldiers in 1942: In German-occupied Yugoslavia, local guerillas sneaked a copy from Greece into an army-cinema in an act of [[Psychological warfare|cultural sabotage]]. After half of the film had been shown, German officers stopped the screening and threatened to shoot the Yugoslavian projectionist. Apparently, the film was ordered by the [[Reich Chancellery]].<ref name="latimes1"/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.spiegel.de/sptv/reportage/a-182140.html|title=Charlie Chaplin und der Führer: Heil Hynkel! |date=14 February 2002|work=Spiegel Online |language=de |accessdate=2015-02-16}}</ref> It was first shown in West Germany as late as 1958. |- |align=center | 1940–1945 | ''[[Carnival in Flanders (film)|La Kermesse Heroïque]]'' (''Carnival in Flanders'') (1935) | Banned in Nazi Germany and Belgium by [[Joseph Goebbels]] because of its pacifist themes. Public use is prohibited as of 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.holocaust-history.org/der-ewige-jude/millersville-19980427.shtml |title=The Eternal Jew - a Blueprint for Genocide |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130708111625/http://www.holocaust-history.org/der-ewige-jude/millersville-19980427.shtml |archivedate=2013-07-08 |df= }}</ref> |- |align=center | 1945- | ''[[Jud Süß (1940 film)|Jud Süss]]'' (1940) | Banned in 1945 from German exhibition by decree of the Allied Military Occupation.<ref name="AJC1951">{{cite book|author=American Jewish Committee|title=Commentary|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lZISAAAAIAAJ|accessdate=2011-10-29|year=1951|publisher=American Jewish Committee}}</ref> Director Veit Harlan was required by court order to destroy what was then believed to be the only remaining negative of ''Jud Süß'' and he reportedly did this in April 1954. A few years later, however, copies of the film began to turn up to the embarrassment of the West German government. After a lengthy investigation, it was determined that another negative existed in [[East Germany]] and it was used it to make prints that were dubbed in Arabic and distributed in Middle Eastern countries such as Egypt and Lebanon. Though that negative has never been located, it has been widely suspected that this version was produced and distributed by the [[Stasi]] or the [[KGB]] in order to arouse anti-semitism among Egyptian and Palestinians against the US backed Israel (and henceforth, support for the Soviet backed Egyptian president [[Gamal Abdel Nasser]]).<ref name="Hull1973">{{cite book|last=Hull|first=David Stewart |title=Film in the Third Reich; art and propaganda in Nazi Germany|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aj8qAAAAYAAJ|accessdate=2011-12-19|year=1973|publisher=Simon and Schuster}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Magill|first=Frank Northen |title=Magill's survey of cinema, foreign language films|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3GZZAAAAMAAJ|year=1985|publisher=Salem Press|isbn=978-0-89356-247-2}}</ref><ref name="Berkeley1960">{{cite book|author=University of California, Berkeley|title=Film quarterly|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Uz8UAAAAIAAJ|accessdate=2011-12-19|year=1960|publisher=University of California Press}}</ref> The copyright of the film is held by the government-owned [[Friedrich Wilhelm Murnau Foundation|F.W. The Ministry of Culture and the Central Partnership issued a joint press release stating that the screening of the film before the 70th anniversary of the [[Victory Day (9 May)|Victory Day]] was unacceptable.<ref name=statement>{{cite web |url= http://mkrf.ru/press-center/news/ministerstvo/sovmestnoe-zayavlenie-ministerstva-kultury-rf-i-kompanii-tsentral-partnership |title=Совместное заявление Министерства культуры РФ и компании "Централ Партнершип" |trans-title=Joint Statement of the Ministry of Culture and the company "Central Partnership" |work=Ministry of Culture of the Russian Federation |date=15 April 2015 |accessdate=2015-04-17 |language=Russian}}</ref> The Ministry of Culture claimed that it received several questions on the film's contents, primarily concerning "distortion of historical facts, peculiar treatment of events before, during and after the [[Great Patriotic War (term)|Great Patriotic War]] and images and characters of Soviet people of that era".<ref name=statement /> Russian minister of culture [[Vladimir Medinsky]] welcomed the decision, but stressed that it was made solely by the Central Partnership. However, in his personal statement Medinsky complained that the film depicts Russians as "physically and morally base sub-humans", and compared the depiction of Soviet Union in the film with J. R. R. Tolkien's [[Mordor]], and wished that such films should be screened neither before the 70th anniversary of the victory in the Great Patriotic War, nor any other time.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://mkrf.ru/press-center/news/ministerstvo/zayavlenie-ministra-kultury-rf-v-r-medinskogo-k-otzyvu-prokatnoy-zayavki-filma-4 |title=Заявление Министра культуры РФ В.Р.Мединского. К отзыву прокатной заявки фильма "No.44" |trans-title=Statement by the Minister of Culture of the Russian Federation V.R.Medinskogo. To review the application of the film "No. 44" |work=Ministry of Culture of the Russian Federation |date=15 April 2015 |accessdate=2015-04-17 |language=Russian}}</ref> However, he also stated that the film would be available in Russia on DVD and online.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/not-in-cinemas-but-child-44-will-be-available-in-russia--culture-minister/519292.html |title=Not In Cinemas, But 'Child 44' Will Be Available in Russia |work=[[The Moscow Times]] |date=17 April 2015 |accessdate=2015-04-18}}</ref> As a result of the decision the film was also withdrawn from cinemas in Belarus,<ref>{{cite web |url= http://tass.ru/en/non-political/789901 |title=Belarus bans Child 44 movie day after Russia |work=[[Russian News Agency "TASS"|TASS]] |date=16 April 2015 |accessdate=2015-04-17}}</ref> Ukraine,<ref>{{cite web |url= http://uatoday.tv/news/hollywood-movie-child-44-will-not-be-shown-in-ukraine-421944.html |title=Hollywood movie 'Child 44' will not be shown in Ukraine |work=[[Ukraine Today]] |date=17 April 2015 |accessdate=2015-04-17}}</ref> Kazakhstan,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://azh.kz/en/news/view/6204|title=American film Child 44 banned in Kazakhstan for distorting history|publisher=}}</ref> and Kyrgyzstan, while release of the film has been postponed until October in [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]].<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/child-44-ban-rolls-soviet-789531 |title='Child 44' Ban Rolls Out Across Former Soviet States |first=Nick |last=Holdsworth |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=17 April 2015 |accessdate=2015-04-18}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1964–1971 | ''[[491 (film)|491]]'' | rowspan="7" align="center" | [[Norway]] | Banned due to [[homosexual]] themes; a censored version was later released.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ovguide.com/491-9202a8c04000641f8000000000b1a9b3 |title=491 Video |publisher=Ovguide.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-12}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1972 | ''[[Pink Flamingos]]'' | Banned on its initial release until the 1980s.<ref name="anothermag1"/> |- |align=center | 1974−1997 | ''[[The Texas Chain Saw Massacre]]'' | Banned due to high impact scary violence. {{COI|date=May 2018}} {{Infobox company | name = MagnaReady | logo = | logo_size = | type = [[Privately Held Company|Private]] | industry = [[Retail]] | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = | founder = Maura Horton | defunct = | location = | location_city = [[Raleigh, North Carolina]] | locations = | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = | products = [[Clothing]] | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | footnotes = | location_country = [[United States]] | homepage = {{URL|http://magnaready.com}} }} '''MagnaReady''' is an [[United States|American]] clothing technology and e-commerce brand based in [[Raleigh, North Carolina]] that produces adaptive clothing for those with dexterity issues. Maura Horton, adaptive clothing pioneer, created MagnaReady in 2013 after her husband, Don Horton struggled buttoning shirts. MagnaReady is the original magnetic shirt technology and it is patented.<ref>{{Citation|title=Article of Clothing Having Magnetic Fastening Assemblies|date=2012-11-12|url=https://patents.google.com/patent/US20140130233A1/en|accessdate=2018-04-09}}</ref> MagnaReady was the first adaptive clothing technology to reach mass market, with the technology licensed to products available at many online retailers.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://eprretailnews.com/2016/09/28/van-heusen-launches-mens-dress-shirt-designed-with-adaptive-technology-that-eliminates-traditional-buttons-3456456483/|title=Van Heusen launches men’s dress shirt designed with adaptive technology that eliminates traditional buttons|work=EPR Retail News|access-date=2017-10-25|language=en-us}}</ref>
== History == In 2009, Don Horton, a [[American football|football]] coach at [[North Carolina State University]], struggled to button his shirt in the locker room due to [[Parkinson's disease]]. That day his shirt was buttoned by [[Russell Wilson]], but his wife, Maura Horton, wanted a better solution for her husband. A former children's clothing designer, she decided to sew magnets into her husband's shirts for ease of use.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2013/04/15/smallbusiness/parkinsons-dress-shirts/index.html|title=Football coach's battle with Parkinson's inspires a line of dress shirts|last=Kavilanz|first=Parija|work=CNNMoney|access-date=2017-10-25}}</ref> In 2015, a patent was granted on the technology developed.<ref>{{Citation|title=Article of Clothing Having Magnetic Fastening Assemblies|date=2012-11-12|url=https://patents.google.com/patent/US20140130233A1/en|accessdate=2018-04-09}}</ref>
In early 2013, after a few years of research, design, and sourcing, the MagnaReady technology was used in shirts launched under a brand by the same namesake. The initial small run of shirts was targeted to elderly men with mobility issues.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2356542/Shirt-magnetic-buttons-invented-wife-Parkinsons-sufferer-gives-independence-people-disabilities.html|title=Wife of Parkinson’s sufferer invents magnetic shirt which closes buttons automatically|work=Mail Online|access-date=2017-10-25}}</ref>
In 2016, [[PVH (company)|PVH Corp.]], producer of Van Heusen, [[Tommy Hilfiger Corporation|Tommy Hilfiger]], [[Calvin Klein]], and IZOD, licensed the MagnaReady technology in order to bring the adaptive shirts to a mass-market audience through stores and e-commerce.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.newsobserver.com/living/fashion/article64945082.html|title=Style Watch: Raleigh-based MagnaReady could get wider reach|work=newsobserver|access-date=2017-10-25|language=en}}</ref> In September 2016, a co-branded line of VanHeusen [[MagnaClick]] shirts were unveiled and marketed to men suffering from Parkinson's disease.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/business/2016/12/09/van-heusen-releases-mens-dress-shirt-with-magnets-instead-of-buttons.html|title=Van Heusen releases men’s dress shirt with magnets instead of buttons|last=Parmley|first=Suzette|date=2016-12-09|work=The Toronto Star|access-date=2017-10-25|language=en-CA|issn=0319-0781}}</ref>
In September 2017, the MagnaReady technology was licensed in a partnership with LF Americas, a division of [[Li & Fung]], to bring the adaptive products to a larger retail audience.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mr-mag.com/lf-americas-license-expand-magnaready-shirt-company/|title=LF AMERICAS TO LICENSE MAGNAREADY SHIRT COMPANY|website=www.mr-mag.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-10-25}}</ref>
In October 2017, a shirt using MagnaReady technology was featured by New York’s [[Museum of Modern Art]] in the ''Items: Is Fashion Modern?'' exhibit as the modern version of a male dress shirt. The exhibit is scheduled to run through January 28, 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://qz.com/1090721/111-iconic-objects-that-defined-the-last-century-of-fashion-according-to-new-yorks-moma/|title=111 iconic objects that defined the last century of fashion, according to New York’s MoMA|last=Bain|first=Marc|work=Quartz|access-date=2017-10-25|language=en-US}}</ref>
==MagnaClick== '''MagnaClick''' is an [[adaptive clothing]] brand based on the MagnaReady technology developed by [[Maura Horton]] that is distributed and sold via licensing of the patented technology.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/business/20161127_Making_a_new_connection_to_certain_dress-shirt_buyers.html|title=Making a new connection to certain dress-shirt buyers - Philly|work=Philly.com|access-date=2018-04-09}}</ref>
=== History === The MagnaClick brand was born in 2016 when MagnaReady technology was licensed to [[PVH Corp.]] to create a line of [[Van Heusen (brand)|Van Heusen]] MagnaClick dress shirts for men. PVH billed it as "a game-changing product that offers a stylish, high quality solution for consumers with limited dexterity or those seeking an alternative to buttons.”<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20160927006727/en/Van-Heusen-Introduces-Adaptive-Clothing-Solution-Major|title=Van Heusen Introduces Adaptive Clothing Solution in Major Retailers Utilizing Hidden Magnetic Closures|access-date=2018-04-09|language=en}}</ref> The shirts were to be sold by select retailers in-store and online in the fall of 2016, including [[Amazon (company)|Amazon]], [[Belk]], [[J. C. Penney|J.C. Penney]] and [[Kohl's|Kohl’s]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://sourcingjournalonline.com/van-heusen-launches-adaptive-magnetic-clothing-solution-for-retailers-gs/|title=Van Heusen Launches Adaptive Magnetic Clothing Solution for Retailers|last=Scarano|first=Genevieve|date=2016-09-29|work=Sourcing Journal|access-date=2018-04-09|language=en-US}}</ref>
In 2017, MagnaClick expanded through a partnership with LF Americas, a division of [[Li & Fung|Li & Fung Limited]]. The partnership will initially expand the brand to men's and women's shirting as well as children's school uniforms. The new MagnaClick line will debut with LF Americas retail partners in 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/magnaready-lf-americas-announce-partnership-133000117.html|title=MagnaReady and LF Americas Announce New Partnership|access-date=2018-04-09|language=en-US}}</ref>

A '''marketing information system''' ('''MKIS''') is a [[management information system]] (MIS) designed to support [[marketing]] [[decision making]]. Jobber (2007) defines it as a "system in which marketing data is formally gathered, stored, analysed and distributed to [[management|manager]]s in accordance with their informational needs on a regular basis." In addition, the online business dictionary defines Marketing Information System (MKIS) as "a system that analyzes and assesses marketing information, gathered continuously from sources inside and outside an organization or a store."<ref>[http://www.businessdictionary.com/definition/marketing-information-system.html Marketing information system], Business Dictionary</ref> Furthermore, "an overall Marketing Information System can be defined as a set structure of procedures and methods for the regular, planned collection, analysis and presentation of information for use in making marketing decisions." (Kotler, at al, 2006)
== Overview == Reid and Bojanic(2010) claimed that, " The term market research informs relatively narrowerly than Marketing Information System(MkIS) which is altered from the term management information [[systemization]]. Market research indicates that information is not collected for a specific reason or project; the major objective is a one-time use. "<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title = Hospitality Marketing Management|last = Reid|first = Robert D.|publisher = John Wiley & Sons,Inc.|year = 2010|isbn = 9780470088586|location = New Jersey|pages = 209|last2 = Bojanic|first2 = David C.|edition = 5th}}</ref>
"A marketing information system, which continuously collects the initial, routine and systematic data, is not only used for one particular topic but is designed for monitoring the degree of the marketing success to ensure the achievable of the operation as well."<ref name=":2" />
== Importance == Developing a MKIS system is becoming extremely important as the strength of economies rely on services and to better understand the specific needs of customers. Kotler, et al. (2006) defined it more broadly as "people, equipment, and procedures to gather, sort, analyze, evaluate, and distribute needed, timely, and accurate information to marketing decision makers."<ref name="Kotler">{{cite book |last=Kotler |first=Philip |authorlink= Philip Kotler |author2=Keller, Kevin Lane |authorlink2=Kevin Lane Keller |editor= |others= |title=Marketing Management |origyear= |url= |format= |accessdate= |edition= 12 |series= |year=2006 |publisher=Pearson Education |location= |isbn= }}</ref>
Insofar as an economy focuses on services, marketing is important to "monitor the marketing environment for changes in [[buyer behavior]] competition, technology, economic conditions, and government policies."<ref>Robert R. Harmon. (2003). Marketing Information Systems. Encyclopedia of Information Systems, Vol. 3. Elsevier Science (USA), 137-151.</ref> In this sense, the role of marketing is becoming pivotal for an organization to "adapt to changes in the market environment." (Harmon, 2003)
As an economy relies on the acquisition of knowledge, MkIS systems are necessary to be able to define and differentiate the [[value proposition]] that one organization provides with respect to another, as well as to define their [[competitive advantage]]. (Harmon, 2003)
The main benefit of MkIS systems is to integrate market-monitoring systems with strategy development and the strategic implementation of policies and processes that help capture and act on [[customer management]] applications with marketing [[decision support system]]s. This area constitute [[Marketing intelligence]] that supports the analysis and market based activities that support customer relations and customer service with real time information with real time applications that support market based approaches.
=== Relevance of MkIS === Shajahan and arya(2004) stated that, "Demands for the MkIS can be expressed by three crucial developments. Firstly, when companies expand and diversify into new markets, both the companies and customer's point of view are needed to be handled by the marketing managers. Therefore, there would be greater need for marketing information. Secondly, when consumers obtain an increment in the level of their income, it causes a tendency for them to be more discriminating during the purchasing procedure. A full awareness of the points that drive a consumer prefer a brand and the points that distinguished his brand from that of the rivals should be obtained by the marketers. This awareness is possible only with the help of a well- designed effective MkIS. Thirdly, the development of the markets and the movement from price to non-price grounds of competition lead to an increase in the importance of adoption and implementation by the competitors and finding the response of the consumers towards them. Analyzing the needs for MkIS from a third person's angle, three more factors come to the forefront viz., the information explosion, increasing complexity in decision making and the technological developments. " <ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title = Management Information Systems|last = Shajahan|first = S.|publisher = New Page International(P) Ltd.|year = 2004|isbn = 8122415490|location = India|pages = 99|last2 = Priyadharshini|first2 = R.}}</ref>
=== Marketing Research(MR)and MkIS ===
In addition, "Great demand of information gathering for marketing decisions results in the need of attention by themselves. Though marketing research information can be generated by studies, which are normally conducted in the market place whereas marketing information systems are designed to gather, integrate, process and distribute marketing information comprehensively from all sources, including that from marketing research. The contrasting characteristics of MkIS and MR are presented in Table 5.1 as shown below:
'''Table 5.1 Showing contrasting characteristic of MR and MkIS''' {| class="MsoTableGrid"
| '''Marketing Research'''
| '''Marketing Information System'''
|- | 1.Emphasis is on handling external information
| 1.It handles both internal and external data.
|- | 2.It is concerned with solving problems.
| 2. It is concerned with preventing as well as solving problems.
|- | 3.It operates in a fragmented fashion – on a project-to-project basis.
| 3.It operates continuously as a system.
|- | 4.It tends to focus on past information.
| 4.It tends to be future oriented.
|- | 5.It is a source of input for marketing information system.
| 5.It includes other subsystems besides marketing research.
|} The business function of marketing is concerned more with the planning, promotion and sale of products in existing markets and the development of new products and new markets. Thus marketing performs a vital function in the operation of a business enterprise. Business firms who turned to computers have been able to perform vital marketing function effectively for organizations' growth in the face of global competition."<ref name=":0" />
== Main Structure == According to Robert Jamon (2003), MkIS systems are decomposed on four components: (1) user interfaces, (2) application software, (3) databases, and (4) system support. The following is a description of each one of these components.
1. [[User interfaces]]. The essential element of the MAkINAS is the managers who will use the system and the interface they need to effectively analyze and use marketing information. The design of the system will depend on what type of decision managers need to make.
2. [[Application software]]. These are the programs that marketing decision makers use to collect, analyze, and manage data for the purpose of developing the information necessary for marketing decisions.
3. [[Database marketing]]. A marketing database is a system in which marketing data files are organized and stored.
4. [[IBM System/34, 36 System Support Program|System support]]. This component consists of system managers who manage and maintain the system assets including software and hardware network, monitor its activities and ensure compliance with organizational policies.
Along with these components, MkIS systems include [[Marketing decision support system|Marketing Decision Support Systems]] (MDSS), which in turn rely on simple systems such as [[Microsoft Excel]], [[SPSS]], and on-line analytical tools that help collect data. Data compiled for analysis is stored and processed from a [[data warehouse]], which is simply a [[Information repository|data repository]] system that helps store and further process data collected internally and externally. (Harmon, 2003)
=== Databases === From Pride and Ferrell (2010), "Internal database is a part of the most marketing information systems. In addition, it's relatively convenient for access and retrieve of information. A databases allow marketers to tap into an abundance of information useful in making marketing decisions: internal sales reports, newspaper articles, company news releases, government economic reports, bibliographies, and more, often accessed through a computer system."<ref>{{Cite book|title = Marketing|last = Pride|first = William M.|publisher = Cengage Learning,Inc.|year = 2010|isbn = 9780547167473|location = Canada|pages = 148|last2 = Ferrell|first2 = O.C.}}</ref>
==== Internal Data ==== In with Birn(2004), " internal data is a part of the data that is needed to be collect and handled by the marketing information system. Further more, managers regard this as a command to make effective operation.But getting the information that is really needed from a marketing information system depends on what the information is and how it is used. The following internal operating data are essential: * Sales data, presented in a graphic format, can provide regular sales trend information and highlight whether certain customer types need to be targeted or focused. * Price information by product line, compare with competitors, can monitor market trends; analyzed by customer type, it can check price trends in customer groups. * Stock level data and trends in key accounts or distributors, focusing on whether different outlets need support, provide market share information. * Market support information, coordinating the effects of marketing promotions, through advertising, direct marketing, trade incentives, consumer competitions and so on, helps to determine whether decisions are being made effectively. * Competitive information, reviewing competitors' promotions and communications to see if the company is doing it better or worse than competitors, can improve market targeting."<ref>{{Cite book|title = The Effective Use of Market Research: How to Drive and Focus Better Business Decisions|last = Birn|first = Robin|publisher = Kogan Page Limited|year = 2004|isbn = 074944200X|location = Great Britain|pages = 22|edition = 4th}}</ref>
=== Environmental scanning === Sandhusen(2000) defined that, environmental scanning is a display of the nature of MIS processed. " It gives assistance for the marketers to develop the strategies, policies, plans and to make programs and budgets through dealing with the ongoing information on trends."<ref>{{Cite book|title = Marketing|last = Sandhusen|first = Richard L.|publisher = Barron's Educational Series|year = 2000|isbn = 9780764112775|location = Canada|pages = 165|edition = 3rd}}</ref>
=== Kotler's Model === According to Philip Kotler, the four components that comprise the MkIS system are Internal Reports (Records) System, Marketing Research System, Marketing Intelligence System, and Marketing Decision Support System
1.Internal Reports System: It records various data from different department of a company, which is regarded as a major source of information.
2.Marketing Intelligence System: It is a main source used by managers for gaining daily information of the external environment, hence assists the managers to react to the changing rapidly.
3.Marketing Research System: It is used to collect primary and secondary data, and displays the results in forms of reports.
4.Marketing Decision Support System: Compared to the supply of the data by the three previous systems, it focuses more on processing the data.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.yourarticlelibrary.com/marketing/mis-marketing-information-system-with-diagram/48703/|title = MIS: Marketing Information System (With Diagram)|date = 2015|accessdate = 1 Nov 2015|website = YourArticleLibrary|publisher = |last = Jaideep|first = S.}}</ref>
== Advantages , Limitations & Possible Risks ==
=== Advantages === Bhasin stated that,"With an increasingly competitive and expanding market, the amount of information needed daily by an organization is profound. So they have to establish a Marketing Information system. There are several advantages of Marketing information systems
* '''Organized Data collection''' – MkIS can help the managers to organize loads of data collected from the market, thus results in an increment in the productivity. * '''A broad perspective''' – With a proper MkIS in place, the organization can be tracked which can be used to analyze independent processes. This helps in establishing a broader perspective which helps us know which steps can be taken to facilitate improvement. * '''Storage of Important Data''' – The storage of important data is essential in execution and thus proves again that MkIS is not important only for information but also for execution. * '''Avoidance of Crisis''' – The best way to analyze a stock (share market) is to see its past performance. Top websites like moneycontrol thrive on MIS. Similarly MIS helps you keep tracks of margins and profits. With an amazing information system established, an organizations direction can be analysed and probably crises averted before they place. * '''Co-ordination''' – Consumer durables and FMCG companies have huge number of processes which needs to be co-ordinated. These companies depend completely on MIS for the proper running of the organization. * '''Analysis and Planning''' – MkIS plays a crucial role in the planning process, considering the planning procedure requires information. For planning, the first thing which is needed is the organizations capabilities, then the business environment and finallycompetitor analysis. In a proper MkIS, all these are present by default and are continuously updated. Therefore, MkIS is very important for planning and analysis. * '''Control''' – Just like MkIS can help in a crisis, in normal times it provides control as you have information of the various processes going on and what is happening across the company."<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url = http://www.marketing91.com/customer-profitablity-analysis-2/|title = 8 Advantages of Marketing Information Systems|date = 23 Oct 2015|accessdate = 23 Oct 2015|website = Marketing 91|publisher = |last = Bhasin|first = Hitesh}}</ref>
=== Possible risks === "Nevertheless, the collection of marketing information should obey a high-frequent manner due to the rapid change in the external market." The possible risks the business may face if they disobey the manner according to Bhasin are:<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.marketing91.com/mis-marketing-information-system/|title = MIS – Marketing information system|date = 23 Oct 2015|accessdate = 23 Oct 2015|website = Marketing 91|publisher = |last = Bhasin|first = Hitesh}}</ref> * Opportunities may be missed. * There may be a lack of awareness of environmental changes and competitors' actions. * [[Data collection]] may be difficult to analyze over several time periods. * Marketing plans and decisions may not be properly reviewed. * Data collection may be disjointed. * Previous studies may not be stored in an easy to use format. * Time lags may result if a new study is required. * Actions may be reactionary rather than anticipatory.
Maintenance, complexity and setting up a MkIS are one of the major hindrances to Marketing information systems. Furthermore, wrong information being fed in MkIS can become cumbersome and appropriate filters need to be established.<ref name=":1" />
=== Limitations === Kotler and Philip have said that "both primary and secondary researches offer loads of the data and information needed for the marketers, whereas the secondary data sources are relatively superior in quick provision of data at lower cost. Simultaneously, a firm cannot find all the data required by itself, but sometimes can be done with the help of secondary research. However, researchers must assess those data collected from both primary and secondary data sources to enable the accuracy, updates and fairness. Each primary data collection method – observational, survey, and experimental – has its own advantages and disadvantages. Similarly, each of the various research contact methods – mail, telephone, personal interview, and online – also has its own advantages and drawbacks." <ref>{{Cite book|title = Principles of Marketing|last = Kotler|first = Philip|publisher = Pearson Education,Inc.|year = 2010|isbn = 9780137006694|location = United States of America|pages = 153|last2 = Armstrong|first2 = Gary|edition = 13th}}</ref>
== Rural Marketing Information System (RuMIS) == A RuMIS is necessary not only for corporate organizations engaged in marketing of agricultural goods and manufactured goods intended for sales in rural areas. RuMIS is required also by the agriculturists and farmers who have enormous decis!ion-making to do.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Rural Marketing: Indian Perspective|last = Singh|first = Awadhesh Kumar|publisher = New Age International (P) Ltd.|year = 2005|isbn = 8122416837|location = India|pages = 114|last2 = Pandey|first2 = Satyaprakash}}</ref>
